School of Chemical and Blasting Engineering Anhui University of Science and Technology Huainan 232001 China Great expectations have been placed on bimetallic co-modified zeolite for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol. In this work, H-ZSM-5 zeolite was modified with bimetallic copper and zinc via ion-exchange method. Numerous experiments were conducted and the methanol yield of 44,302.70 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 was obtained over 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst. A series of characterization analyses confirmed that the introduction of Zn increased the proportion of active Cu species bound to extra-framework oxygen by altering the electronic state of copper. The bis (μ-oxo) dicopper ligand was identified as the active site for methane oxidation. The possible reasonable reaction pathway was the free radical reaction. This work provides a valuable guidance for the preparation of co-modified zeolite catalysts for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol. Abstract graph Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol Methane oxidation Bimetallic synergistic effect Bis (μ-oxo) dicopper ligand Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane is widely regarded as a highly effective gaseous fuel, mainly originating from coalbed methane, shale gas, natural gas, and combustible ice. However, the limited means of direct utilization as fuels restrict its further development and application [1]. Meanwhile the methane leakage problem in transportation and storage often leads to environmental pollution [2–4]. The conversion of low-energy-density methane into other high-value-added chemicals has gained widespread recognition [5–7]. Therefore, it is essential to develop efficient technologies for converting methane into liquid fuels or commodity chemicals that are convenient to store, transport and utilize. For decades, the competent catalytic oxidation of methane to methanol has drawn considerable attentions due to its great potential in solving the environment and energy problem. At present, the methane oxidation route adopted by industry is the Fischer-Tropsch process though a syngas (CO and H2) intermediate [8–11]. Nevertheless, this indirect process is high consumption of energy and quite complicated [12,13]. Thus, the direct oxidation of methane to methanol (DMTM) under relatively mild conditions is quietly desired. The activation of the CH bond (438.8 kJ·mol−1) of the non-polar CH4, while preventing over-oxidation of CH3OH formed, makes the DMTM reaction considerably challenging [14–19]. Numerous studies have been carried out in finding and fabricating advanced catalysts for resolving this contradiction. Plentiful of noble metal catalysts such as Au, Pd, Ru, Rh [20–24] have been introduced due to their excellent capacity in methane activation. Whatever, these samples are not very suitable for the conversion of methane to methanol for large-scale application considering either expensive price or complicated synthesis methods. In nature, the methanol was produced by methanotrophic bacteria under mild and appropriate conditions using methane monooxygenase (particulate enzyme, pMMO) compriseing mononuclear and binuclear centers with copper cations [25–28]. Inspired by pMMO, inexpensive inorganic biomimetic zeolite catalysts with mononuclear or binuclear Cu as active sites are expected to fulfill the DMTM reaction under mild conditions. Various zeolites such as ZSM-5, MOR, etc. have been used as catalyst carriers due to their special framework structure and unique acidic surface [29–35]. Copper-modified zeolite catalysts for the DMTM reaction have aroused great interests among researchers [36–39]. Gabrienko et al. [40] studied the properties of active sites on H-ZSM-5 zeolite with low copper loading and pointed out that Z[Cu(II)O], Z[Cu(II)(OH)], and Z2Cu(II) are Cu2+ cations bound to the H-ZSM-5 zeolite framework Si-O-Al sites. Yashnik et al. [41] concluded that binuclear Cu(II) formed by Cu and extra-framework oxygen is more active compared to isolated Cu2+ ions and CuO nanoparticles. It has been confirmed that catalysts with mononuclear or binuclear Cu as active sites over zeolites are indeed able to catalyze the DMTM reaction under mild conditions. Tang et al. [42] reported an atomically dispersed copper-modified zeolite catalyst achieved a higher methanol yield than most other catalysts, demonstrating that metal dispersion has an affect on catalytic performance. In additon, Yu et al. [43] also showed that the atomically dispersed Ag1 Cu1/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a higher methanol yield than the nanoparticle Agp-Cup/ZSM-5 catalyst and the electronic state and coordination structure of the Cu species are modulated by the influence of Ag. Transition metals [44–47] such as Zn were used as metal promoters for the industrial methanol synthesis process. Kuld et al. [48] confirmed that the introduction of Zn species nanoparticles enhance the reaction rate but Zn did not be active in methanol synthesis reaction. Huang et al. [49] found that the ZnOCu2O step site were active center for the DMTM reaction. The defected O-rich Zn species introduced by Zn vacancies demonstrated outstanding catalytic activity. Thus, Zn has the potential to enhance catalytic performance of catalysts for the DMTM reaction. Herein, we co-modified commercial H-ZSM-5 zeolite with both copper and zinc via ion-exchange method [50,51] and applied for DMTM reaction under mild conditions with H2O2 as oxidant. The effects of reaction temperature and reaction time on methanol yield have been validated by extensive experiments. A series of characterization methods, including TEM, HADDF-STEM, BET, XRD, XPS, UV–Vis DRS and ESR were conducted to analyses the possible relationship between the physicochemical properties and methanol yield. Possible reaction pathway was described. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Materials Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 99 %) and Standard zinc-nitrate solution (Zn(NO3)2, 100 g/L) were respectively purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. and Beijing North Weiye Measurement Technology Research Institute Co., Ltd.; H2O2 (≥ 30 %) was purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co.,Ltd.; The support materials H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 21,27,50,80) were obtained from Nankai University Catalyst Co.,Ltd.. 2.1.2 Pre-treatment of H-ZSM-5 In order to eliminate the effects of adsorbed water and organic templates and impurities remained in the zeolite pores, it is imperative for commercial H-ZSM-5 to be pretreated via high-temperature calcination. The appropriate amount H-ZSM-5 was calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h. The pre-treated H-ZSM-5 should be used as soon as possible. 2.1.3 Preparation of catalysts The catalysts were prepared by the ion-exchange method (Scheme 1 A). Typically, 2 g pre-treated H-ZSM-5 was dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water. The requisite quantitie metal precursors of copper and zinc (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Zn(NO3)2) were dissolved with 20 mL of deionized water and the pH of the mixture solutions were maintained between 3.0 and 4.0. Then the mixed metal precursor solution was pumped into the H-ZSM-5 suspension at a rate of 0.5 mL·min−1 under stirring. After overnight ageing at room temperature, the samples were filtered, washed using deionized water until the pH = 7.0, dried at 60 °C in an oven for 4 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The calcined samples were denoted as xCu/yZn-ZSM-5 (x and y refer to the molar ratios of copper and zinc precursors added during the preparation of the samples, respectively). The actual metal loading amount were shown in Table S1. Additionally, as controls, xCu-ZSM-5 and yZn-ZSM-5 need to be prepared using the same method. All the experiments were performed at least in duplicate. 2.2 Characterization of catalyst materials The metal loading amount in the catalysts were determined by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) using the Agilent 5110 (OES) instrument. The fully automatic surface area and porosity analyzer (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2460) was used to measure the specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume of catalysts. The specific surface areas were calculated using the Brunaure-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore size and pore volume were obtained based on the Barrett-JoynerHalenda (BJH) method using the desorption branches of N2 isotherm. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) as well as the corresponding elemental mapping (EDS) images were performed on a FEI Talos F200x. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were recorded on Rigaku SmartLab SE, scanning from 5°to 60°with a step size of 0.02°. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted utilizing a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Al-Kα source (hv = 1486.6 eV, 12 kV, 6 mA) to determine the chemical states of copper and zinc. Charge correction was performed using the C1 s binding energy at 284.80 eV as the energy reference standard. Surface metal species were acquired based on UV–visible diffuse reflectance (UV–vis DRS) spectra performed on Shimadzu UV-3600 in the range of 200–800 nm with BaSO4 as a reference material. CH4-temperature program desorption (CH4-TPD) and NH3-TPD were conducted via the Microtrac BELCat II. Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) Spectra of JEOL JES-FA200 ESR was employed to detect the free radicals in the reaction solution. 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic activity The catalytic performance of as-prepared samples were conducted in a 100 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with mechanical stirring. Typically, 20 mg catalyst was dispersed in 40 mL of 0.5 mol·L −1 H2O2 aqueous solution. And then the reactor was sealed. Subsequently, the reactor was purged and charged with 99.9 % CH4 to 3.0 MPa. The mixture was heated to target temperature and maintained a certain amount of reaction time under vigorous stirring. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was immediately cooled in a mixture of ice and water to reduce the loss of volatile products. The catalyst performance testing procedure is shown in Scheme 1B. Methanol in the reaction solution were quantitatively measured using a gas chromatograph (GC 5190 plus, JN.TDX-01 column) equipped with an FID detector (Fig. S1A). Other oxygenates in liquid products were detected via 1H NMR spectroscopy of Bruker Ascend TM 600 MHz instrument. The solvent suppression technique was used to minimize the interference from H2O signals during NMR measurement. Typically, 0.7 mL of the product solution was mixed with 0.1 mL of D2O (with approximately 0.02 wt.% DSS). The main oxygenates identified by 1H NMR include HCOOH (δ = 8.27), CH2(OH)2 (δ = 5.04), CH3OOH (δ = 3.86), CH3OH (δ = 3.35), DSS (δ = 0.00) (Fig. S2). Note that all the liquid-phase samples should be filtered with 0.22 um Nylon-66 filter to remove catalyst particles and calrified solutions were stored in refrigerator before analysis. The gas-phase products such as hydrogen (H2), oxygen (O2), carbon dioxide (CO2) and unreacted methane (CH4) were collected into a gas sampling bag, and then further analyzed by GC5190 plus instrument equipped with a TCD detector (Fig. S1B). In addition, methanol yield is calculated using the following formula: C H 3 OH yield ( μ mol / g cat / h ) = C H 3 OH amount Catalyst amount × Reaction time C H 3 OH selectivity ( % ) = C H 3 OH amount ( n [ C O 2 ] + n [ C H 3 OH + C H 3 OOH + HCOOH + C H 2 ( OH ) 2 ] ) × 100 % C H 4 conversion rate ( % ) = ( [ C H 4 ] start − [ C H 4 ] final ) [ C H 4 ] start × 100 % where the CH 3 OH amount (μmol) represents the total content of methanol in liquid products, Catalyst amount (g) represents the total amount of catalyst added to the reactor in each reaction, The unit of Reaction time is hours (h), the [CH 4 ] start stands for initial concentration of CH4, and [CH 4 ] final refers to the residual concentration of CH4 after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphological characterization The XRD patterns of the xCu/yZn-ZSM-5 catalysts (1Cu-ZSM-5, 2Zn-ZSM-5 and 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5) are presented in Fig. 1 A. All diffraction peaks of the metal-loaded samples were assigned to the spinel structure of bare H-ZSM-5 (PDF#44–033) and the standard diffraction peaks associated with copper or zinc species were not detected. The probable reasons were as follows: (i) the metals species were highly dispersed on the zeolite; (ii) the contents of Cu species and Zn species on 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 were very low (0.47 wt% Cu and 0.11 wt% Zn determined by ICP-OES, Table S1) [52,53]. (iii) The metal particle size falls outside the detectable range. Anyway XRD patterns showed that the introduction of metals have no significant effect on the structure and crystallinity of the zeolite. These above observations was also further confirmed by the results of BET tests (Fig. 1B and Table S2). All the catalyst samples have a mesoporous structure since their hysteresis loops were observed at relative pressures ranging from 0.4 to 1.0 [53] . There was also no obviously change in Dpore and Vpore of between these modified zeolite catalysts and H-ZSM-5. But the SBET of modified zeolite catalysts showed a certain decrease due to some of the micropores in the zeolite were filled by the metals introduced compared with H-ZSM-5. And this decrease was especially obvious in the catalyst 2Zn-ZSM-5, but not observed in the 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 sample, indicating that the dispersion of zinc was promoted by copper. In addition, the increase in the amount of ·OH radicals after the introduction of Zn was clearly observed from the ESR experiments (Fig. 8B). The high methanol yield on 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 was attributed to the synergistic effect of copper and zinc. The TEM and HADDF-STEM were performed to further elucidated the microstructure of 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 (Fig. 2 ). No distinct metal particles or clusters were observed at either low or high magnification (Fig. 2, Fig. S3C). The EDS images also revealed that the copper and zinc species are indeed evenly dispersed on the zeolite. There results are consistent with that of XRD and BET. In addition, CH4-TPD (Fig. S4) confirmed that the introduction of Zn not only increased the methane adsorption capacity but also reduced the activation energy for methane adsorption, making the DMTM reaction easier to occur. The NH3-TPD experiments was employed to investigate the effects of metal doping on acidity of catalysts (Fig. 3 A). There were two major desorption peaks at about 200 °C and 450 °C on the NH3-TPD curve of parent H-ZSM-5, representing the adsorption of NH3 on weak and strong Brønsted acid sites, respectively [54]. Previous studies reported that the strong acid sites on the H-ZSM-5 zeolite are composed of the protonic acid sites, whereas the weak acid sites are correlated with the silicon hydroxyl groups [55]. After metal loading, the peak of desorption for either weak acid or strong acid sites over all the catalysts significantly reduced comparing to bare H-ZSM-5 (Fig. 3A). In particular, the desorption peak of 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 decreased notably. Meanwhile, the peak intensity of 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst was lower than that of 1Cu-ZSM-5, which means that the interaction of Cu and Zn due to the introduction of Zn consumed more protons or altered more silicon hydroxyl groups. The coordination states and aggregation extent of Cu and Zn species in the catalysts were analyzed by UV–Vis DRS (Fig. 3B). It can be seen that the narrow absorption band at 217 nm over Cu-containing catalysts has significantly strengthened in contrast to H-ZSM-5, which could be attributed to Cu2+ species bound to zeolite framework [56]. On the other hand, 1Cu-ZSM-5 and 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 samples also exhibited a broad absorption band over 650 nm caused by the d-d electronic transition of CuO particles [57]. The peak intensity of 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 samples obviously decreased compared with 1Cu-ZSM-5 samples, suggesting the number of cupric oxides in samples was reduced. This reduction could be ascribed that more Cu form other Cu species besides CuO particles in the samples. and the changes about electronic states of Cu species resulted from the introduction of Zn [52]. The results above indicated that there was some interaction between Cu and Zn in 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were employed to further investigate the chemical states of Cu and Zn species in the catalyst (Fig. 4 A,B). About copper zeolite catalyst, the oxidation state of copper in the active site was mainly divalent but existing in various forms such as Cu-OH, mono(μ-oxo) dicopper sites, bis (μ-oxo) dicopper sites, and tricopper sites [58,59]. Two distinct peaks at around 933.6 eV and 936.1 eV are presented on 1Cu-ZSM-5 and 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 samples. The binding energy (B.E) of 933.5–934.5 eV were attributed to CuO nanoparticles, and peaks with B.E exceeding 936.0 eV were assigned to bis (μ-oxo) dicopper [58,59]. The bis (μ-oxo) dicopper bound to the zeolite framework Si-O–Al sites [40]. Furthermore, as it can be seen from Fig. 4C and Table S3 that the proportion of CuO (933.6 eV) decreased from 73.67 % in 1Cu-ZSM-5 to 65.53 % in 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5, and meanwhile the bis (μ-oxo) dicopper (936.1 eV) increased 26.33 % to 34.47 %, which meant that the introduction of Zn in 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst enhanced amount of active species which was conducive to the oxidation of methane to methanol. Two characteristic peaks at around 1022.6 and 1024.3 eV were presented on 2Zn-ZSM-5 and 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 samples. The lower binding energy (1022.6 eV) was assigned to ZnO species [55]. The peak at 1024.3 eV was belonging to Zn2+ cations in the cation exchange sites and the higher B.E indicated the presence of Zn2+ cations strongly interacting with the H-ZSM-5 zeolite [52,60]. From Fig. 4A-C, it can be seen that the interaction of Cu-Zn in 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst improved the Zn2+ cations from 35.89 % to 50.93 % compared with 2Zn-ZSM-5, while the amount of ZnO reduced by 15.04 %. This phenomenon signified that the dispersion of Zn on 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst was better than that on 2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst. One signal peak (Fig. S5) at around 532.6 eV was confirmed as the framework oxygen [61]. In a word, the interactions between metal-zeolite or metal-metal enhance the proportion of active species on the catalyst. 3.2 Catalyst performance The effect of the amount of Cu and Zn precursor salts added to the ion exchange solution on the methanol yield were shown in Fig. 5 . And H-ZSM-5, 1Cu-ZSM-5 and 2Zn-ZSM-5 were also investigated as controls. The 1Cu-ZSM-5 sample exhibited relatively good catalytic performance among this series of Cu-only samples. The amount of copper precursor salt added was selected as the baseline to further investigate the effect of zinc doping on methanol yield in the DMTM reaction. Fig. 5B indicated that the methanol yield over 1Cu-ZSM-5 sample was much higher than the parent H-ZSM-5 sample. The 2Zn-ZSM-5 sample showed negligible improvement in methanol yield. Therefore, Cu species were the main active component in this reaction system, not Zn. The molar amount of Cu-Zn precursor salts in the ion exchange solution were adjusted to optimize the optimal ratio of Cu-Zn precursor salt during catalyst preparation. Meanwhile, with the increasing of Zn precursor salt added over xCu/yZn-ZSM-5 samples, the methanol yield showed a obviously increasing tendency at first and then decreased. The methanol yield of 34,206.474 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 was obtained when the molar ratio of Cu-Zn precursor salt in the ion exchange solution was 1:2. This results indicated that the doping of Zn over the catalysts had a noticeable impact on the DMTM reaction. It was known that copper oxide formed in catalysts was not conducive to improvement of methanol yield in DMTM reaction [53]. The XPS and UV–Vis DRS analysis above demonstrated that when Zn species were introduced into catalyst the electronic state of Cu2+ species was modulated which resulted in the decrease of copper oxide and a higher presence of active Cu species in the form of bis (μ-oxo) dicopper. According to the analysis above, it could be inferred that a moderate amount doping of Zn indeed was beneficial to the formation of active sites for the improvement of methanol yield. In view of appreciable catalytic performance over 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalysts for DMTM reaction, more detailed parameters were studied to obtain the optimal reaction conditions and the results were summarized in Table S4 and Fig. 6 . The methanol yield and total oxygenates yield showed a Gaussian-like trend from rising to decline with the increase of temperature. The methanol yield and total oxygenates yield reached 44,302.70 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 95,820.76 μmol·gcat −1·h −1, respectively, at 90 °C. The methanol yield decreased when the reaction temperature was above 90 °C, especially at 110 °C, the methanol yield dramatically decreased. The yield of the other C1 products such as HCOOH keeps improving with increasing of the reaction temperature (Fig. 6A) and even CO2 was detected at 110 °C. It was also noticed that methanol selectivity kept dropping throughout the temperature range from 50 to 110 °C, more pronounced during 90–110 °C. In addition, the lowest methanol yield while the highest methanol selectivity of 77.14 % observed at 50 °C, which may be related to the difficulty in activating methane at this temperature [56]. The tendency of yield and selectivity of methanol varied with the reaction temperature could be attributed to the dissociation products of H2O2 at different temperatures. H2O2 could be spontaneously decomposed to O2 or to free radicals (·OH or ·OOH) over the synthesized catalysts according to reaction temperature. On the one hand, modest radicals could be beneficial to improve the yield of methanol. However, if more free radicals was produced, the formed methanol was also facile to further be oxidized into other C1 products such as HOCH2OH, HCOOH, CO2, namely that over-oxidation reactions were occurred [24,42,43]. ESR testing (Fig. 8A,B) showed that ·OH was produced in the reaction DMTM reaction by 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 sample. On the other hand, H2O2 can spontaneously decomposed into H2O and O2 instead of ·OH at higher temperature condition (> 90 °C) [53], which may affect the selectivity to methanol. The effects of reaction time on 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 were also studied and shown in Fig. 6B. The methanol selectivity presented a declining trend with prolonging reaction time from 15 to 60 min due to the over-oxidation reaction of methanol. And the maximum yield of methanol was obtained at a reaction time of 30 min. Si/Al ratio experiments were conducted to screen out a suitable ZSM-5 for this reaction system (Fig. 7 A). It was shown that the catalyst exhibited better performance in the reaction system when the Si/Al ratio of the support was 27. The result of the comparison between the 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 sample in our work and other catalysts recently reported has been presented (Fig. 7B). This result demonstrated that the catalyst using copper and zinc as modifiers to co-modify H-ZSM-5 zeolites has promising outlook for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol under mild conditions. Electron Spin Resonance radical trapping experiments were conducted using DMPO and the results were showed in Fig. 8 . Two type of radicals namely ·OH and ·OOH were detected in the DMTM reaction using 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5. Thus, it was reasonable to inferred that the oxidation reaction about methane to methanol was triggered by the radicals produced from H2O2 decomposition over 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5. The intensity of ·OH was much higher than that of ·OOH at 50 °C, meaning ·OH played a major role in this reaction system (Fig. 8A). A higher concentration of ·OH radicals in the reaction system catalyzed by 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 was detected compared to 1Cu-ZSM-5 (Fig. 8B). Previous studies suggested active Cu species could promote the selective disassembly of H2O2 into ·OH radicals in the DMTM reaction [62,63]. XPS showed that the content of bis (μ-oxo) dicopper was increased after the introduction of Zn, resulting in more ·OH radicals formed and subsequently affecting methanol yield. This explanation was testified in the experiments Fig. 5. In addition, various Cu-oxo complexes (including monomers, dimers, and trimers) were considered as the active sites for DMTM reaction on Cu-zeolite catalysts. In our work, bis (μ-oxo) dicopper formed by Cu2+ species bound to the zeolite framework oxygen was active sites since the binding energy appeared around 936.1 eV [52,58,60]. Therefore, The reaction pathway using the bis (μ-oxo) dicopper as active sites in DMTM reaction catalyzed by 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 was reasonably speculated (Fig. 8C). The CH4 are adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The active site efficiently cleaves the CH bond to form *CH3. The radicals generated by H2O2 abstract the metal-adsorbed *CH3 to form ·CH3. The ·CH3 quickly reacted with ·OH radicals to produce methanol, which is the main reaction route in our experiments. However, the excess ·OH radicals in the liquid-phase would further attack the methanol formed, leading to over-oxidation to formic acid or methylene glycol. The above-mentioned conclusion can be supported by the experiments about the testing of catalytic performance in Fig. 6. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have prepared high-performance bimetallic 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst by adjusting the molar ratio of metal precursor salts in the ion exchange solution during the preparation process. The 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 achieves a methanol yield of 44,302.70 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 90 °C for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol in the presence of H2O2. Based on catalytic performance tests and characterization results, we demonstrate that bis (μ-oxo) dicopper is the main active site for methane oxidation in this reaction system. Methane adsorbed on the active site was activated by ·OH radicals to generate ·CH3. The ·OH radicals rapidly combine with ·CH3 to form methanol. The roles of Zn species on 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 are enhancing the proportion of active Cu species and increasing methane adsorption capacity, which facilitate the occurrence of this reaction. The amount of ·OH radicals detected by ESR was higher than ·OOH radicals. This is a key factor for methanol being the main product in this reaction system. However, the CH3OH was peroxide-oxidized to HCOOH, resulting in a reduced methanol selectivity. These findings provide some references for the design of bimetallic co-modified zeolite catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Great expectations have been placed on bimetallic co-modified zeolite for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol. In this work, H-ZSM-5 zeolite was modified with bimetallic copper and zinc via ion-exchange method. Numerous experiments were conducted and the methanol yield of 44,302.70 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 was obtained over 1Cu/2Zn-ZSM-5 catalyst. A series of characterization analyses confirmed that the introduction of Zn increased the proportion of active Cu species bound to extra-framework oxygen by altering the electronic state of copper. The bis (μ-oxo) dicopper ligand was identified as the active site for methane oxidation. The possible reasonable reaction pathway was the free radical reaction. This work provides a valuable guidance for the preparation of co-modified zeolite catalysts for the direct oxidation of methane to methanol.
